children.text: Indicator 1: Use procedures to transform algebraic expressions.
(Comprehension) Explain the relationship between repeated addition and multiplication.
(Knowledge) Identify special properties of 0 and 1 with respect to arithmetic operations (addition, subtraction, multiplication).
(Comprehension) Simplify whole number expressions involving addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division.
(Application) Recognize and use the commutative property of addition and multiplication.
(Application) Relate the concepts of addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division to one another.
(Application) Use a variable to write an addition expression.
(Application) Recognize and use the associative property of addition and multiplication.
(Application) Use order of operations, excluding nested parentheses and exponents, to simplify whole number expressions.
(Application) Write algebraic expressions involving addition or multiplication using whole numbers.
(Application) Write and evaluate algebraic expressions using the set of whole numbers.
(Knowledge) Identify associative, commutative, distributive, and identity properties involving algebraic expressions.
(Application) Use properties to expand, combine, and simplify 1st degree algebraic expressions with the set of integers.
Indicator 2: Use a variety of algebraic concepts and methods to solve equations and inequalities.
(Comprehension) Compare collections of objects to determine more, less, and equal (greater than and less than).
(Comprehension) Use the concepts and language of more, less, and equal (greater than and less than) to compare numbers and sets (0 to 20).
(Application) Solve open addition and subtraction sentences with one unknown () using numbers equal to or less than 10.
(Comprehension) Use concepts of equal to, greater than, and less than to compare numbers  (0-100).
(Application) Solve open addition and subtraction sentences with one unknown using numbers equal to or less than 20.
(Application) Balance simple addition and subtraction equations using sums up to 20.
(Comprehension) Select appropriate relational symbols (<, >, =) to compare numbers.
(Application) Solve problems involving addition and subtraction of whole numbers.
(Comprehension) Select appropriate relational symbols (<, >, =) to make number sentences true.
(Application) Simplify a two-step equation using whole numbers.
(Application) Write one-step first degree equations using the set of whole numbers and find a solution.
(Application) Write and solve one-step 1<sup>st</sup> degree equations, with one variable, involving inverse operations using the set of whole numbers.
(Application) Write and solve one-step 1st degree  equations, with one variable, using the set of integers and inequalities, with one variable, using the set of whole numbers.
(Application) Write and solve two-step 1st degree equations, with one variable, and one-step inequalities, with one variable, using the set of integers.
Indicator 3: Interpret and develop mathematical models.
(Knowledge) Use concrete objects to model the meaning of the "+" and "-"  symbols.
(Application) Students are able to write number sentences from problem situations using + or - and = with numbers to 10.
(Application) Write and solve number sentences from word problems.
(Application) Use the relationship between multiplication and division to compute and check results.
(Application) Write and solve number sentences that represent one-step word problems using whole numbers.
(Application) Write and solve number sentences that represent two-step word problems using whole numbers.
(Application) Identify information and apply it to a given formula.
(Knowledge) Identify and graph ordered pairs in Quadrant I on a coordinate plane.
(Application) Solve one-step problems involving ratios and rates.
(Application) Identify and graph ordered pairs on a coordinate plane and inequalities on a number line.
(Application) Model and solve multi-step problems involving rates.
(Comprehension) Describe and determine linear relationships.
Indicator 4: Describe and apply the properties and behaviors of relations, functions and inverses.
(Knowledge) Identify and extend two-part repeating patterns using concrete objects.
(Comprehension) Sort and classify objects according to one attribute.
(Comprehension) Identify and extend repeating patterns containing multiple elements using objects and pictures.
(Comprehension) Determine common attributes in a given group and identify those objects that do not belong.
(Comprehension) Find and extend growing patterns using symbols, objects, and numbers.
(Comprehension) Determine likenesses and differences between sets.
Indicator 4: Describe and use the properties and behaviors of relations, functions, and inverses.
(Comprehension) Extend linear patterns.
(Application) Use number patterns and relationships to learn basic facts.
(Application) Solve problems involving pattern identification and completion of patterns.
(Application) Solve problems using patterns involving more than one operation.
Indicator 4: Analyze and describe the properties and behaviors of relations, functions, and their inverses.
(Comprehension) Use concrete materials, graphs, and algebraic statements to represent problem situations.
(Application) Recognize one-step patterns using tables, graphs, and models and create one-step algebraic expressions representing the pattern.
(Synthesis) Create rules to explain the relationship between numbers when a change in the first variable affects the second variable.
(Analysis) Describe and represent relations using tables, graphs, and rules.
Indicator 1: Use deductive and inductive reasoning to recognize and apply properties of geometric figures.
(Knowledge) Identify basic two-dimensional (plane) figures.
(Comprehension) Describe characteristics of plane figures.
(Comprehension) Sort basic three-dimensional figures.
(Comprehension) Use the terms side and vertex (corners) to identify plane and solid figures.
(Comprehension) Recognize and compare the following plane and solid geometric figures: square, rectangle, triangle, cube, sphere, and cylinder.
(Knowledge) Identify points, lines, line segments, and rays.
(Knowledge) Identify the following plane and solid figures: pentagon, hexagon, octagon, pyramid, rectangular prism, and cone.
(Knowledge) Identify parallel, perpendicular, and intersecting lines.
(Knowledge) Describe and identify isosceles and equilateral triangles, pyramids, rectangular prisms, and cones.
(Knowledge) Identify acute, obtuse, and right angles.
(Comprehension) Identify and describe the characteristics of triangles and quadrilaterals.
(Comprehension) Identify and describe angles.
(Application) Identify, describe, and classify polygons having up to 10 sides.
(Knowledge) Identify and describe elements of geometric figures.
Describe and classify prisms, pyramids, cylinders, and cones.
(Application) Given any two sides of an illustrated right triangle, use the Pythagorean Theorem to find the third side.
Indicator 2: Use properties of geometric figures to solve problems from a variety of perspectives.
(Comprehension) Describe the position of two-dimensional (plane) figures.
(Comprehension) Describe proximity of objects in space.
(Knowledge) Identify geometric figures regardless of position and orientation in space.
(Comprehension) Demonstrate relationships between figures using similarity and congruence.
(Comprehension) Compare geometric figures using size, shape, orientation, congruence, and similarity.
(Knowledge) Identify a slide (translation) of a given figure.
(Comprehension) Determine lines of symmetry in rectangles, squares, and triangles.
(Knowledge) Identify a turn or flip (rotation or reflection) of a given figure.
(Application) Use two-dimensional coordinate grids to find locations and represent points and simple figures.
(Application) Use basic shapes to demonstrate geometric concepts.
(Application) Demonstrate ways that shapes can be transformed.
(Application) Write and solve proportions that express the relationships between corresponding parts of similar quadrilaterals and triangles.
Indicator 1: Apply measurement concepts in practical applications.
(Knowledge) Tell time to the hour using analog and digital clocks.
(Knowledge) Name the days of the week.
(Knowledge) Identify pennies, nickels, dimes, and quarters using money models.
(Knowledge) Estimate length using non-standard units of measure.
(Comprehension) Compare and order concrete objects by length, height, and weight.
(Knowledge) Tell time to the half-hour using analog and digital clocks and order a sequence of events with respect to time.
(Application) Find a date on the calendar.
(Application) Use different combinations of pennies, nickels, and dimes to represent money amounts to 25 cents.
(Comprehension) Estimate weight using non-standard units of measure.
(Knowledge) Identify appropriate measuring tools for length, weight, capacity, and temperature.
(Comprehension) Compare and order concrete objects by temperature and capacity.
(Knowledge) Tell time to the minute using analog and digital clocks and relate time to daily events.
(Application) Use the calendar to solve problems.
(Application) Determine the value of a collection of like and unlike coins with a value up to $1.00.
(Knowledge) Represent and write the value of money using the "¢" sign and in decimal form using the "$" sign.
(Comprehension) Use whole number approximations for capacity using non-standard units of measure.
(Comprehension) Solve everyday problems by measuring length to the nearest inch or foot.
(Application) Locate and name concrete objects that are about the same length, height, weight, capacity, and temperature as a given concrete object.
(Knowledge) Read and tell time on an analog clock before the hour and after the hour within five-minute intervals.
(Application) Count, compare, and solve problems using a collection of coins and bills.
(Knowledge) Identify U.S. Customary units of length (feet), weight (pounds), capacity (gallons).
(Application) Select appropriate units to measure length (inch, foot, mile, yard); weight (ounces, pounds, tons); and capacity (cups, pints, quarts, gallons).
(Knowledge) Measure length to the nearest <sup>1</sup>/<sub>2</sub> inch
(Knowledge) Identify equivalent periods of time and solve problems.
(Application) Solve problems involving money including unit conversion.
(Application) Use scales of length, temperature, capacity, and weight.
(Comprehension) Measure length to the nearest quarter-inch.
(Comprehension) Determine elapsed time within an a.m. or p.m. period on the quarter-hour.
(Application) Solve problems involving money including making change.
(Application) Use and convert U.S. Customary units of length (inches, feet, yard), and weight (ounces, pounds).
(Application) Use appropriate tools to measure length, weight, temperature, and area in problem solving.
(Comprehension) Select, use, and convert appropriate unit of measurement for a situation.
(Comprehension) Find the perimeter and area of squares and rectangles (whole number measurements).
(Comprehension) Select, use, and convert appropriate unit of measurement for a situation including capacity and angle measurement.
(Comprehension) Given the formulas, find the circumference, perimeter, and area of circles, parallelograms, triangles, and trapezoids (whole number measurement).
(Application) Apply proportional reasoning to solve measurement problems with rational number measurements.
(Comprehension) Find area, volume, and surface area with whole number measurements.
Indicator 1: Analyze the structural characteristics of the real number system and its various subsystems. Analyze the concept of value, magnitude, and relative magnitude of real numbers.
(Comprehension) Read, write, count, and sequence numerals to 20.
(Knowledge) Use fraction models to create one half of a whole.
(Application) Solve addition and subtraction problems up to 10 in context.
(Comprehension)  Read, write, count, and order numerals to 50.
(Knowledge) Use unit fraction models to create parts of a whole.
(Comprehension)  Read, write, count, and sequence numerals to 100.
(Comprehension) Identify and represent fractions as parts of a group.
Indicator 2: Apply number operations with real numbers and other number systems.
(Application) Solve addition and subtraction problems with numbers 0 to 20 written in horizontal and vertical formats using a variety of strategies.
(Application) Solve two-digit addition and subtraction problems written in horizontal and vertical formats using a variety of strategies.
Indicator 3: Develop conjectures, predictions, or estimations to solve problems and verify or justify the results.
(Application) Students are able to solve addition and subtraction  problems up to 10 in context.
(Application) Solve addition and subtraction problems up to 20 in context.
(Application) Solve addition and subtraction problems up to 100 in context.
(Application) Use various strategies to solve one- and two-step problems involving positive decimals.
(Application) Use various strategies to solve one- and two-step problems involving positive fractions and integers.
(Application) Use various strategies to solve multi-step problems involving rational numbers.
Indicator 1: Use the structural characteristics of a set of real numbers and its various subsets.
(Comprehension) Order and compare whole numbers less than 10,000 using appropriate words and symbols.
(Comprehension) Find multiples of whole numbers 2, 5, and 10.
(Knowledge) Name and write fractions from visual representations.
(Comprehension) Read, write, order, and compare numbers from .01 to 1,000,000.
(Comprehension) Find multiples of whole numbers through 12.
(Comprehension) Use a number line to compare numerical value of fractions or mixed numbers (fourths, halves and thirds).
(Application) Interpret negative integers in temperature.
(Comprehension) Read, write, order, and compare numbers from .001 to 1,000,000,000.
(Comprehension) Find prime, composite, and factors of whole numbers from 1 to 50.
(Knowledge) Identify alternative representations of fractions and decimals involving tenths, fourths, halves, and hundredths.
(Comprehension) Locate negative integers on a number line.
(Comprehension) Determine the squares of numbers 1 – 12.
Indicator 2: Apply operations within the set of real numbers.
(Application) Add and subtract whole numbers up to three digits and multiply two digits by one digit.
(Application) Find the products of two-digit factors and quotient of two natural numbers using a one-digit divisor.
(Application) Add and subtract decimals with the same number of decimal places.
(Application) Find the quotient of whole numbers using two-digit divisors.
(Application) Determine equivalent fractions including simplification (lowest terms of fractions).
(Application) Multiply and divide decimals by natural numbers (1 – 9).
(Comprehension) Add, subtract, multiply, and divide decimals.
(Application) Add, subtract, multiply, and divide integers and positive fractions.
(Application) Read, write, and compute within any subset of rational numbers.
Indicator 3: Develop conjectures, predictions, or estimations in the process of problem solving and verify or justify the results.
(Application) Round two-digit whole numbers to the nearest ten and three-digit whole numbers to the nearest hundred.
(Application) Estimate sums and differences in whole numbers and money to determine if a given answer is reasonable.
(Application) Use different estimation strategies to solve problems involving whole numbers, decimals, and fractions to the nearest whole number.
Indicator 1:	Use the structural characteristics of the set of real numbers and its various subsets. Apply the concept of value, magnitude, and relative magnitude of real numbers.
(Comprehension) Represent fractions in equivalent forms and convert between fractions, decimals, and percents using halves, fourths, tenths, and hundredths.
(Knowledge) Find factors and multiples of whole numbers.
(Comprehension) Represent numbers in a variety of forms by describing, ordering, and comparing integers, decimals, percents, and fractions.
(Application) Find and use common multiples and factors of whole numbers.
(Comprehension) Represent numbers in a variety of forms and identify the subsets of rational numbers.
Indicator 1: Use statistical models to gather, analyze, and display data to draw conclusions.
(Knowledge) Describe data represented in simple graphs (using real objects) and pictographs.
(Application) Display data in simple picture graphs with units of one and bar graphs with intervals of one.
(Comprehension) Answer questions from organized data.
(Comprehension) Use interviews, surveys, and observations to gather data.
(Application) Represent data sets in more than one way.
(Comprehension) Answer questions about and generate explanations of data given in tables and graphs.
(Application) Ask and answer questions from data represented in bar graphs, pictographs, and tally charts.
(Application) Gather data and use information to complete a scaled and labeled graph.
(Application) Interpret data from graphical representations and draw conclusions.
(Knowledge) Given a small ordered data set of whole number data points (odd number of points), students will identify the median, mode, and range.
(Application) Gather, graph, and interpret data.
(Application) Calculate and explain mean for a whole number data set.
(Comprehension) Find the mean, mode, and range of an ordered set of positive data.
(Application) Display data using bar and line graphs and draw conclusions from data displayed in a graph.
(Comprehension) Find the mean, median, mode, and range of a set of data.
(Application) Display data, using frequency tables, line plots, stem-and-leaf plots and make predictions from data displayed in a graph.
(Comprehension) Find the mean, median, mode, and range of a data set from a stem–and-leaf plot and a line plot.
(Application) Use a variety of visual representations to display data to make comparisons and predictions.
Indicator 2: Apply the concepts of probability to predict events/outcomes and solve problems.
(Comprehension) Recognize whether the outcome of a simple event is possible or impossible.
(Application) List possible outcomes of a simple event and make predictions about which outcome is more or less likely to occur.
Indicator 2: Apply the concepts of probability to predict outcomes and solve problems.
(Comprehension) Describe events as certain or impossible.
(Comprehension) Determine the probability of simple events limited to equally likely and not equally likely outcomes.
(Application) Classify probability of simple events as certain, likely, unlikely, or impossible.
(Application) Use models to display possible outcomes.
Indicator 2: Apply the laws of probability to predict outcomes and solve problems.
(Knowledge) Find the probability of a simple event.
(Comprehension) Given a sample space, find the probability of a specific outcome.
(Comprehension) Find the sample space and compute probability for two simultaneous independent events.
Indicator 1: Use procedures to transform algebraic expressions.
Core HS Standards
(Comprehension)Write equivalent forms of algebraic expressions using properties of the set of real numbers.
Advanced HS Standards
(Application) Write equivalent forms of rational algebraic expressions using properties of real numbers.
(Application) Extend the use of real number properties to expressions involving complex numbers.
Indicator 2: Use a variety of algebraic concepts and methods to solve equations and inequalities.
Core HS Standards
(Comprehension) Use algebraic properties to transform multi-step, single variable, and first-degree equations.
(Application) Use algebraic properties to transform multi-step, single variable, and first-degree inequalities and represent solutions using a number line.
Advanced HS Standards
(Analysis) Determine solutions of quadratic equations.
(Application) Determine the solution of systems of equations and systems of inequalities.
(Application) Determine solutions to absolute value statements.
Indicator 3:  Interpret and develop mathematical models.
Core HS Standards
(Application) Create linear models to represent problem situations.
(Comprehension) Distinguish between linear and nonlinear models.
Advanced HS Standards
(Analysis) Distinguish between linear, quadratic, inverse variations, and exponential models.
(Synthesis) Create formulas to model relationships that are algebraic, geometric, trigonometric, and exponential.
(Analysis) Use sequences and series to model relationships.
Indicator 4:	Describe and use properties and behaviors of relations, functions, and inverses.
Core HS Standards
(Application) Use graphs, tables, and equations to represent linear functions.
Advanced HS Standards
(Analysis) Determine the domain, range, and intercepts of a function.
(Analysis) Describe the behavior of a polynomial, given the leading coefficient, roots, and degree.
(Analysis) Apply transformations to graphs and describe the results.
(Application) Apply properties and definitions of trigonometric, exponential, and logarithmic expressions.
(Analysis) Describe characteristics of nonlinear functions and relations.
(Application) Graph solutions to linear inequalities.
Indicator 1: Use deductive and inductive reasoning to recognize and apply properties of geometric figures.
Core HS Standards
(Application) Apply the properties of triangles and quadrilaterals to find unknown parts.
(Application) Identify and apply relationships among triangles.
Advanced HS Standards
(Evaluation) Justify properties of geometric figures.
(Application) Determine the values of the sine, cosine, and tangent ratios of right triangles.
(Application) Apply properties associated with circles.
(Analysis) Use formulas for surface area and volume to solve problems involving three-dimensional figures.
Indicator 2: Use properties of geometric figures to solve problems from a variety of perspectives.
Core HS Standards
(Analysis) Recognize the relationship between a three-dimensional figure and its two-dimensional representation.
(Application) Reflect across vertical or horizontal lines, and translate two-dimensional figures.
(Application) Use proportions to solve problems.
Advanced HS Standards
(Synthesis) Use Cartesian coordinates to verify geometric properties.
Indicator 1:	Apply measurement concepts in practical applications.
Core HS Standards
(Comprehension) Choose appropriate unit label, scale, and precision.
(Comprehension) Use suitable units when describing rate of change.
(Application) Use formulas to find perimeter, circumference, and area to solve problems involving common geometric figures.
Advanced HS Standards
(Application) Use dimensional analysis to check answers and determine units of a problem solution.
(Analysis) Use indirect measurement in problem situations that defy direct measurement.
Indicator 1:	 Analyze the structural characteristics of the real number system and its various subsystems.  Analyze the concept of value, magnitude, and relative magnitude of real numbers.
Core HS Standards
(Comprehension) Identify multiple representations of a real number.
(Comprehension) Apply the concept of place value, magnitude, and relative magnitude of real numbers.
Advanced HS Standards
(Comprehension) Describe the relationship of the real number system to the complex number system.
(Application) Apply properties and axioms of the real number system to various subsets, e.g., axioms of order, closure.
Indicator 2: Apply operations within the set of real numbers.
Core HS Standards
(Comprehension) Add, subtract, multiply, and divide real numbers including integral exponents.
Advanced HS Standards
(Application) Add, subtract, multiply, and divide real numbers including rational exponents.
Indicator 3: Develop conjectures, predictions, or estimations to solve problems and verify or justify the results.
Core HS Standards
(Analysis) Use estimation strategies in problem situations to predict results and to check the reasonableness of results.
(Comprehension) Select alternative computational strategies and explain the chosen strategy.
Advanced HS Standards
Note: Skills for this indicator have been subsumed within applications to advanced skills by the time students reach advanced high school mathematics.
Indicator 1:	Use statistical models to gather, analyze, and display data to draw conclusions.
Core HS Standards
(Analysis) Draw conclusions from a set of data.
(Comprehension) Compare multiple one-variable data sets, using range, interquartile range, mean, mode, and median.
(Analysis) Represent a set of data in a variety of graphical forms and draw conclusions.
Advanced HS Standards
(Evaluation) Analyze and evaluate the design of surveys and experiments.
(Evaluation) Analyze and evaluate graphical displays of data.
(Analysis) Compare multiple one-variable data sets, using standard deviation and variance.
(Application) Describe the normal curve and use it to make predictions.
(Application) Use scatterplots, best-fit lines, and correlation coefficients to model data and support conclusions.
Indicator 2: Apply the concepts of probability to predict events/outcomes and solve problems.
Core HS Standards
(Knowledge) Distinguish between experimental and theoretical probability.
(Comprehension) Predict outcomes of simple events using given theoretical probabilities.
Advanced HS Standards
(Application) Use probabilities to solve problems.
(Application) Determine probability of compound, complementary, independent, and mutually exclusive events.
(Analysis) Generate data and use the data to estimate empirical probabilities.
